channel.title: BBC News - UK Politics

item.title: Boris Johnson faces leadership criticism amid partygate row
item.description: Boris Johnson deflects questions over his future, but a senior Tory MP says a no confidence vote is likely.

item.title: Stormy week puts PM's position back in frame
item.description: Unexpected developments made the past few days more difficult than expected for Boris Johnson.

item.title: Ukraine: UK embassy in Kyiv to reopen next week, says PM
item.description: Boris Johnson announces the embassy in Ukraine is set to open its doors again after Russia's invasion.

item.title: Johnson vows to deepen trade ties with India after talks with PM Modi
item.description: The PM wants a deal "done" by October - but warned there will be "tough asks" from both sides.

item.title: Brexit: Boris Johnson not ruling out law to override protocol
item.description: Boris Johnson says he will continue talking to the EU to seek reforms, but won't rule out further steps.

item.title: Fake Jill Mortimer Twitter accounts all claim to be Hartlepool MP
item.description: The real Jill Mortimer's office confirms the Hartlepool MP is not on the social media platform.

item.title: NHS to ban products of slavery after PPE concerns
item.description: A campaign group says it is the biggest step in removing forced labour from supply chains in years.

item.title: Scout commissioner asks Tory MP Sarah Atherton not to attend event
item.description: An MP was asked not to attend a Scouts event so its "non-political" message was not "muddied by recent controversial incidents and policies".

item.title: Tory donor’s 'link' to sanctioned oligarch’s secret London property
item.description: A major donor was listed as a director of a firm secretly owned by a Russian oligarch close to Putin.

item.title: MPs say asbestos must go from public buildings within 40 years
item.description: A date must be set to "focus minds" on getting rid of the deadly substance, a Commons committee says.

item.title: Fuller review into ferries deal needed, MSPs told
item.description: Scotland's auditor general says it would be too "glib" to say lessons could be learned over failings.

item.title: Boris Johnson ignores Labour call to apologise to Archbishop
item.description: Sir Keir Starmer demands an apology over comments Boris Johnson made to a private meeting of Tory MPs.

item.title: Evgeny Lebedev peerage was 'special case', says chair of vetting committee
item.description: Lord Bew denies any interference to his vetting, despite reports the PM overruled security concerns.

item.title: I'm anxious about menopause - Nicola Sturgeon
item.description: Scotland's first minister says she is in the "foothills" of menopause and has worried about its impact.

item.title: Fake reviews to be illegal under new rules
item.description: The government has also announced people will be able to opt out of subscriptions more easily.

item.title: Julian Assange's US extradition order sent to Priti Patel for final approval
item.description: A court has approved an order for the Wikileaks founder to face espionage charges in the US.

item.title: Partygate: Which Downing Street parties have resulted in fines so far?
item.description: The police inquiry is separate to the investigation carried out by civil servant Sue Gray.

item.title: Brexit: Cross-border permits will damage industry, say NI Tourism
item.description: The proposal will require non-British and non-Irish EU citizens to apply for pre-travel clearance.

item.title: Minister compares PM party penalty to speeding fine
item.description: Brandon Lewis's comments are described as an "insult to bereaved families".

item.title: Jacob Rees-Mogg calls for civil servants to return to the office
item.description: A "clear message" must be sent to civil servants about ending home working, minister says.

item.title: Rwanda asylum seeker policy: Ex-PM Theresa May criticises government plan
item.description: The government says plans to send some asylum seekers to Rwanda will deter the work of people smugglers.

item.title: Ukraine war: Only third of UK's £220m humanitarian aid delivered by 1 April
item.description: Only £60m of £220m humanitarian aid pledged by the government was handed out by 1 April, a Labour MP says.

item.title: No 10 network targeted with spyware, says group
item.description: Researchers say they warned UK officials about being targeted, but the software's makers deny the claims.

item.title: Horse Guards Parade: Man accused of police confrontation
item.description: Prashanth Kandaiah is accused of attempting to cause grievous bodily harm and possessing a knife.

item.title: Sturgeon reported to police for not wearing mask
item.description: Footage shows Nicola Sturgeon without a mask during a visit to a barber shop in East Kilbride.

item.title: Rwanda asylum critics have no solutions, says Patel
item.description: The home secretary responds after criticism of her refugee plan from the Archbishop of Canterbury.

item.title: Sewage: Ban water firm bonuses until discharges end, Lib Dems say
item.description: Bosses paid £27m extra since 2020 despite 1,000 sewage spills a day, according to the party's research.

item.title: UK's Rwanda asylum plan the 'opposite of nature of God' - Welby
item.description: There were "serious ethical questions" over sending migrants to east Africa, Justin Welby says.

item.title: Boris Johnson and Prince Charles remember war in Ukraine in Easter messages
item.description: Addressing Ukrainians in their language, Boris Johnson urged them to "be strong".

item.title: No 10 parties: PM's lockdown fine constitutional crisis, says historian
item.description: A leading expert says Boris Johnson "broke the law", "misled Parliament" and "shredded the ministerial code".

item.title: Johnson to visit India in bid to boost defence ties
item.description: The prime minister will meet his Indian counterpart after previous visits were postponed due to Covid.

item.title: Ukraine war: Russia bans Boris Johnson from country over Ukraine war
item.description: Boris Johnson and other senior ministers are barred for "whipping up anti-Russian hysteria".

item.title: Tory MP Imran Ahmad Khan quits after sexual assault conviction
item.description: Imran Ahmad Khan's decision to stand down after a sex assault verdict will trigger a by-election.

item.title: PM vows to set record straight over claims he misled MPs over parties
item.description: Boris Johnson vows to "set the record straight" over claims he lied to Parliament over Partygate.

item.title: Russia sanctions: UK freezes assets of Abramovich associates
item.description: Eugene Tenenbaum and David Davidovich have had their assets - estimated to be up to £10bn - frozen.

item.title: May 2022 UK elections: How to vote
item.description: Voters are choosing councillors in England, Scotland and Wales, and a government in Northern Ireland.

item.title: UK elections 2022: A really simple guide
item.description: Local elections in England, Wales and Scotland, and a general election in Northern Ireland, will happen on 5 May.

item.title: Election 2022: Is there an election in my area?
item.description: National elections in Northern Ireland and local elections in the rest of the UK happen on 5 May 2022.

item.title: England local elections 2022: What's at stake for the parties?
item.description: Elections in England this year will reflect voters' views on the cost-of-living crisis, says the BBC's Alex Forsyth.

item.title: NI election 2022: Why Northern Ireland's election is different
item.description: Parties make pledges but the nature of Northern Ireland's government means they're harder to honour.

item.title: Scotland elections 2022: Five things to watch in May's council vote
item.description: Elections for all 32 Scottish local councils will be held on 5 May. Here are some of the things to look out for.

item.title: NI election 2022: Campaigners say change needed to get more women into Stormont
item.description: A record number of women are standing in the NI election - but more needs to change, say campaigners.

item.title: Johnson: UK will reopen Kyiv embassy next week
item.description: Paying tribute to British diplomats, the PM says the UK will open its Ukrainian embassy within days.

item.title: Ros Atkins On… The PM and the Ministerial Code
item.description: Boris Johnson will be investigated by a Commons committee over claims he misled Parliament.

item.title: Sunak on Partygate fine, US green card, family finances and non-dom status
item.description: The UK chancellor gives his first interview since he was fined for attending a party at Downing Street.

item.title: Starmer withdraws comments on PM, BBC and Ukraine
item.description: The Labour leader has withdrawn his criticism of Boris Johnson about the BBC's reporting of the Ukraine War.

item.title: Johnson wants Partygate investigators to 'do their stuff'
item.description: The PM says he is "very keen for every possible form of scrutiny" over claims he misled the Commons over lockdown parties.

item.title: What did Boris Johnson tell Parliament about parties?
item.description: MPs are set to investigate whether the prime minister misled Parliament.

item.title: Whisky and visas could be part of a UK-India trade deal
item.description: Boris Johnson is hoping to strike a free trade deal with India within months.

item.title: Partygate: A timeline of the lockdown gatherings
item.description: The prime minister has apologised for attending Downing Street drinks during lockdown, how many other gatherings were there?

item.title: Boris Johnson party row: What has the PM said before?
item.description: Watch to see previous times Boris Johnson responded to claims of parties at Downing Street.

item.title: Downing Street parties: What Covid rules were broken?
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Chancellor Rishi Sunak fined for breaking Covid regulations.

item.title: Will there be more fines for No 10 parties?
item.description: Boris Johnson and Rishi Sunak have already paid penalties, but the police probe isn't over yet.

item.title: Cumbria coal mine: What is the controversy about?
item.description: Cumbrian councillors are reviewing their support for a controversial coal mine near Whitehaven.

item.title: Rishi Sunak: What we know about his family’s wealth
item.description: As the finances of the chancellor and his wife come under scrutiny, we look at their business interests.

item.title: 'I don't want rising bills to mean kids miss out'
item.description: Taxes and bills are rising, so how do small businesses - already hit by Covid - think they'll cope?

item.title: Privatising Channel 4: What could new ownership mean and who might buy it?
item.description: What difference could selling the channel to a private owner make for viewers, and who might buy it?

item.title: Partygate fines: Are Boris Johnson and Rishi Sunak finished?
item.description: The prime minister and chancellor are in uncharted waters over fines for breaking lockdown laws.

item.title: Energy: What does the UK's new strategy say?
item.description: The blueprint places a major focus on boosting supplies from nuclear plants and offshore wind.

item.title: Jamie Wallis: Transgender community in Wales reacts to first trans MP
item.description: Jamie Wallis, Tory MP for Bridgend, has made history - becoming the first MP to come out as trans.

item.title: Whatever happened to Rishi Sunak's political honeymoon?
item.description: The chancellor's ratings are slumping, with colleagues questioning his chances of becoming PM.

item.title: Don't forget families like us, Covid bereaved tell inquiry chief
item.description: The head of the UK Covid inquiry, Baroness Hallett, is talking to people who lost loved ones in the pandemic.

item.title: What is going on with the partygate probe?
item.description: Stories about Covid rule breaking in No 10 have gone away but police activities are continuing.

item.title: Spring Statement: Is this really the biggest personal tax cut for 25 years?
item.description: The Spring Statement cut some taxes but, overall, the government has raised taxes in the past year.

item.title: Solar farms: Can expansion overcome Tory MPs' concerns?
item.description: Ministers hope solar farms can vary the UK's energy mix - but they face increasing local opposition.

item.title: Spring Statement: Key points at a glance
item.description: The chancellor laid out his Spring Statement amid a cost of living squeeze. Here's what you should know.

item.title: How Rishi Sunak's Spring Statement will affect you
item.description: Surging prices, National Insurance changes and fuel duty cuts - the impact on your finances explained.

item.title: Say Yes To Tess: Turning a doomed election campaign into a musical
item.description: Tess Seddon has made a stage show out of standing for parliament for the Yorkshire Party.

item.title: Spring Statement: 'It's the economics of the madhouse'
item.description: Businesses and individuals react to Chancellor Rishi Sunak's Spring Statement.

item.title: What is the UK's inflation rate and why is the cost of living going up?
item.description: UK inflation is rising at 7%, its fastest rate for 30 years, and some say it could go even higher.

item.title: Five ways the Ukraine war could push up prices
item.description: Prices for everyday items could go up at a time when the cost of living is already rising.

item.title: Are the P&O Ferries sackings legal?
item.description: P&O has been widely criticised for sacking 800 employees - but were its actions illegal?

item.title: Cost of living: What Tory MPs want from Rishi Sunak
item.description: MPs are not short of ideas for the chancellor to help struggling families, but all come at a price.

item.title: How do the UK's schemes for Ukrainian refugees work?
item.description: How is the government helping Ukrainian refugees come to the UK?

item.title: Climate change: Can the Russian energy crisis help to curb global heating?
item.description: An energy strategy is due - but can it get the UK off Russian gas, cut bills and help the environment?

item.title: Russia oligarchs: The mega-rich men facing global sanctions
item.description: President Putin has for years warned Russia's richest to protect themselves against sanctions.

item.title: Why have there been delays to UK Russia sanctions?
item.description: Many Russians were sanctioned more quickly by the EU and US than the UK.

item.title: Sanctions on Russia: Did the UK sanction 100 people last week?
item.description: The prime minister claimed it was 100, but the real number is much lower.

item.title: Net zero: Tory faction tests Johnson support for climate target
item.description: Boris Johnson’s 2050 emissions target is being challenged by a band of his own MPs.

item.title: Whipped: Why MPs are getting out of line
item.description: BBC correspondent Ben Wright examines whether the traditional system of disciplining MPs is breaking down.

item.title: What sanctions are being imposed on Russia over Ukraine invasion?
item.description: Western nations have imposed severe sanctions on Russia over its invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Climate change: Can the UK afford its net zero policies?
item.description: The cost of living crisis has led backbench Conservative MPs to call for a rethink of the government's plans.

item.title: Ukraine crisis: How much Russian money is there in the UK?
item.description: The UK is imposing further sanctions against Russian interests, but some think more should be done.

item.title: Sue Gray party report: What are the findings?
item.description: Initial findings from the senior official's inquiry into No 10 lockdown parties have been published.

item.title: Cabinet reshuffle 2022: Who is in Boris Johnson's cabinet?
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson reshuffles his cabinet for the first time since September 2022. Who's in it now?

item.title: Can the UK really improve inequalities without big spending?
item.description: The government has allocated £4.8bn as part of its plan to "level up" all UK regions, but will this be enough?

item.title: Givan resignation triggers fresh political crisis in NI
item.description: The first and deputy first minister can't operate in isolation; when one goes so does the other.
